word.entryDescription: things that change the sun's energy into energy for a building
word.entryExample: The sun's energy is stored in solar panels and converted to electricity.

word.entryDescription: energy produced by the sun
word.entryExample: Greenhouse gases are the gases in the earth's atmosphere that absorb solar radiation and emit it to the atmosphere as heat, warming the surface of the earth.

word.entryDescription: a member of an army
word.entryExample: Many soldiers died in the war, and even more were wounded.

word.entryDescription: to find the answer to a problem
word.entryExample: That crime took a really long time to solve – detectives were investigating it for years.

word.entryDescription: a quantity of
word.entryExample: There's some sugar in the cupboard.

word.entryDescription: a time phrase used to introduce / link events
word.entryExample: Some time later, I was persuaded to to give a short speech to the rest of the class.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to a person when it is not important to say exactly who
word.entryExample: Please tell Kate you're busy doing something important with someone else this weekend!

word.entryDescription: used for giving a description or amount that is not exact
word.entryExample: Can you tell me something about your new teacher?

word.entryDescription: on some occasions
word.entryExample: I sometimes read in the evenings.

word.entryDescription: your male child
word.entryExample: My son wants to be a fire-fighter like me.

word.entryDescription: having knowledge and good judgement relating to the world, life, culture, fashion, etc
word.entryExample: My sister's style is quite sophisticated – she loves dressing up in stylish clothes.

word.entryDescription: a pain inside your throat
word.entryExample: I've got a terrible sore throat, I think I might be getting flu – or an infection!

word.entryDescription: wanted by many people but difficult to get or find
word.entryExample: Tickets are much sought-after and bought online months before the event.

word.entryDescription: to seem, from what you hear or read
word.entryExample: We decide if things sound too loud or too quiet.

word.entryDescription: someone whose job is concerned with the recording, mixing and reproduction of sound
word.entryExample: Tom is a sound engineer. He is responsible for recording the audio for things like text books and audio books.

word.entryDescription: resemble the sound of something
word.entryExample: They don't sound like guitars.

word.entryDescription: the music from a film
word.entryExample: 'The soundtrack is fantastic,' he told me.

word.entryDescription: a dish of hot liquid, often containing meat and vegetables
word.entryExample: Would you like some tomato soup?

word.entryDescription: having a sharp acid taste like vinegar
word.entryExample: Lemons are sour.

word.entryDescription: the direction that is normally at the bottom of a map
word.entryExample: I come from the south of England.

word.entryDescription: a continent made up of all the countries in the lower half of America
word.entryExample: The Amazon river is in South America.

word.entryDescription: something you bring back from a trip to remind you of it
word.entryExample: There is a shop at Paddington station where you can buy souvenirs of Paddington Bear.

word.entryDescription: the seed of a soya (a plant from which oil and food containing a lot of protein is produced)
word.entryExample: Are these soya beans being used to fatten chickens and cows?

word.entryDescription: the area outside the Earth which contains the Moon, other planets, the stars, etc
word.entryExample: I'm an astronaut and I often go on space missions.

word.entryDescription: a large spacecraft that is sent into space and stays above the Earth as a base for people working and travelling in space
word.entryExample: There aren't any showers on the space station!

word.entryDescription: email messages that you do not want, which are usually advertising something
word.entryExample: Avoid spam and help keep your inbox tidy by only entering it when it's absolutely necessary.

word.entryDescription: to be able to say words, have a conversation or talk in a language
word.entryExample: Excuse me, do you speak English?

word.entryDescription: (usually plural) unusual images, sounds or sequences specially produced to make a play, film, etc more appealing or enjoyable
word.entryExample: The special effects in this film are stunning and captivating.

word.entryDescription: a group of living things with members that are very similar to one another and can breed together
word.entryExample: There are currently around 5000 species of endangered animals and 25,000 species of endangered plants.

word.entryDescription: somebody who attends a sport or game in order to watch it for entertainment
word.entryExample: The tennis match attracted more than 10,000 spectators.

word.entryDescription: a special camera which takes photographs of vehicles that are being driven too fast
word.entryExample: When we see speed cameras we just start braking and slowing down until we’re beyond their vision.

word.entryDescription: the fastest that you are allowed to drive in a particular place
word.entryExample: Speed controlled cars make sure cars slow down and obey speed limits.

word.entryDescription: the offence of driving faster than the limit
word.entryExample: Do you think speeding should be illegal?

word.entryDescription: to put the letters in a word in the correct order
word.entryExample: Can you spell your name?

word.entryDescription: having a burning taste in the mouth like chillies
word.entryExample: Do you like spicy food?

word.entryDescription: a small creature with eight legs that usually catches its food in a web
word.entryExample: Can you see this big, black spider on the window?

word.entryDescription: to turn quickly and repeatedly around a central point
word.entryExample: Ballet dancers are very good staying upright while they spin around.

word.entryDescription: a vegetable with dark green leaves
word.entryExample: They say that spinach makes you strong.

word.entryDescription: the line of bones that run down the middle of the back from the head to the bottom
word.entryExample: Lifting heavy boxes can damage your spine.

word.entryDescription: to tear or break along a straight line
word.entryExample: Oh no – my skirt has split. And I'm on my way to a job interview!

word.entryDescription: a tool with a handle and a small bowl which you use for eating, mixing or serving food
word.entryExample: Can you bring me a spoon, please?

word.entryDescription: a special bag made of leather or fur, that is worn by Scotsman in front of the kilt as part of their national dress
word.entryExample: Kilts are traditionally worn with a leather pouch called a sporran.

word.entryDescription: a building in which you can do different kinds of sports and physical activities
word.entryExample: You can go swimming at the local sports centre.

word.entryDescription: (of clothes) looking attractive in a bright informal way; looking suitable for wearing for sports
word.entryExample: She was wearing a sporty jacket and skirt.

word.entryDescription: to notice somebody or something
word.entryExample: I spotted my friend in the crowd but he didn't see me.

word.entryDescription: covered or decorated in spots
word.entryExample: Emma is wearing a scarf and a spotted sweater.

word.entryDescription: husband or wife
word.entryExample: Their father is Alfred and their mother, Rebecca, is Alfred's spouse.

word.entryDescription: to damage a joint in your body by twisting it suddenly
word.entryExample: When I stepped down I sprained my ankle.

word.entryDescription: to put a layer of substance over the surface of something
word.entryExample: Mike spread his toast with butter, jam and peanut butter.

word.entryDescription: to move over a wider area or affect a greater number of people
word.entryExample: The flooding is spreading across the region.
